awd_titl_txt: Molecular Dynamics of Chemical Reactions and Interactions at Liquid/Liquid Interfaces
awd_abstract_narration:
Many important chemical reactions occur at the interface between water and organic liquids, such as oil. This interfacial environment is particularly challenging for computational simulations of chemical reactions because of the complexity of molecular interactions. With support from the Chemical Structure Dynamics and Mechanism A (CSDM-A) program in the Division of Chemistry, Professor Ilan Benjamin of the University of California at Santa Cruz is using sophisticated simulation tools to understand how a proton travels across the water-oil interface. The gained knowledge could impact research in the areas of chemical catalysis, clean energy production and storage.  It could also provide insight into understanding respiration and photosynthesis. The project provides students opportunities working at the interface of computational and experimental chemical research.  Professor Benjamin also works closely with students from underrepresented minority groups.  

The project focuses on several elementary processes that are crucial for understanding recent experiments on proton transfer reactions at liquid interfaces. These elementary processes include 1) weak and strong acid ionization at the interface between water and several organic liquids; 2) proton transfer across the interface to a surface-active proton acceptor; and 3) proton transfer facilitated by a phase transfer catalyst. These processes are studied mainly using the empirical valence-bond methodology, which enables efficient examination of the complex interfacial system with sufficient statistical accuracy. Fundamental questions addressed include the molecular mechanism of the proton transfer, influence of surface fluctuations on transfer dynamics, and influence of external potential on the rate and thermodynamics of the proton transfer.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Many chemical reactions of importance to environmental sciences, energy storage, and catalysis occur at the interface between liquid water and organic solvents. Our work has provided a molecular-level detailed understanding of molecular interactions and reactivity at the interface.  Advances in surface-specific experimental techniques have provided numerous new results on the spectroscopy and reactivity of chemical species at liquid interfaces. By direct comparison with experimental data, our project has provided a complementary understanding of these systems. Specifically, our work has provided new insight into the important problem of the mechanism of proton transfer across the water/oil interface. Understanding the mechanism of proton transport is crucial for several important technological goals such as clean energy production and storage, liquid/liquid extraction and for organic synthesis. Due to the proton’s high affinity to water the transfer is typically facilitated electrochemically by an applied voltage or by the association of the proton with surface active or water-insoluble species with high affinity for protons or with the help of a Phase Transfer Catalyst. Our extensive molecular dynamics simulations have provided for the first time molecular level insight into the above mechanisms. We have shown that surface water structure plays an important role in facilitating the proton transfer and that taking this into account is important factor for the design of new catalysts and for the general understanding of chemical reactivity at the interface between water and oil. In addition to the broad impact on developing new technologies in area such as environmental chemistry, energy storage, and catalysis the graduate students working on this project receive training in theoretical and computational chemistry. The close collaboration with experimentalists provided additional benefits to the students working on this project.
